Privet: A Privacy-Preserving Vertical Federated Learning Service for Gradient Boosted Decision Tables

Yifeng Zheng, Shuangqing Xu, Songlei Wang, Yansong Gao, and Zhongyun Hua Yifeng Zheng, Shuangqing Xu, Songlei Wang, and Zhongyun Hua are with the School of Computer Science and Technology, Harbin Institute of Technology, Shenzhen, Guangdong 518055, China (e-mail: yifeng.zheng@hit.edu.cn, shuangqing.xu@outlook.com, songlei.wang@outlook.com, huazhongyun@hit.edu.cn). Yansong Gao is with Data61, CSIRO, Sydney, Australia (e-mail: gao.yansong@hotmail.com). Corresponding author: Zhongyun Hua.
Abstract

Vertical federated learning (VFL) has recently emerged as an appealing distributed paradigm empowering multi-party collaboration for training high-quality models over vertically partitioned datasets. Gradient boosting has been popularly adopted in VFL, which builds an ensemble of weak learners (typically decision trees) to achieve promising prediction performance. Recently there have been growing interests in using decision table as an intriguing alternative weak learner in gradient boosting, due to its simpler structure, good interpretability, and promising performance. In the literature, there have been works on privacy-preserving VFL for gradient boosted decision trees, but no prior work has been devoted to the emerging case of decision tables. Training and inference on decision tables are different from that the case of generic decision trees, not to mention gradient boosting with decision tables in VFL. In light of this, we design, implement, and evaluate Privet, the first system framework enabling privacy-preserving VFL service for gradient boosted decision tables. Privet delicately builds on lightweight cryptography and allows an arbitrary number of participants holding vertically partitioned datasets to securely train gradient boosted decision tables. Extensive experiments over several real-world datasets and synthetic datasets demonstrate that Privet achieves promising performance, with utility comparable to plaintext centralized learning.

Index Terms:
Vertical federated learning service, multi-party collaboration, gradient boosting, decision table, privacy preservation

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) has recently emerged as a fascinating distributed machine learning paradigm that greatly empowers multi-party collaboration for mining value over data federation [1, 2, 3, 4]. It allows distributed individual training datasets to be kept locally, and only intermediate outputs from the training algorithm are shared out for aggregation. According to how data is distributed among the participants in FL, there are two types of FL: horizontal federated learning (HFL) [5, 6] and vertical federated learning (VFL) [7, 8]. HFL addresses the scenario where the participants share the same feature space but hold disjoint sets of samples/instances, which generally suits the case that participants are individual customers. In contrast, VFL targets the scenario where each participant has the same set of samples/instances yet owns data for different features, which is more common when the participants are business organizations/enterprises. For example, as illustrated in Fig. 1, the participants hold datasets that have the same row indexes (corresponding to the same set of instances) but different non-overlapping column indexes (corresponding to different features). In this paper, we focus on the VFL setting, which has received increasing attentions in the collaboration of different business organizations/enterprises in recent years [8, 9].

For model training in the VFL setting, the gradient boosting technique has received wide attentions [10, 8, 7, 11, 9] and has seen popular adoption for empowering a wide range of fields, such as web search ranking, online advertisement, and fraud detection [12, 13, 14]. Gradient boosting builds an ensemble of weak learners, which are typically (generic) decision trees, to achieve promising prediction performance. While decision tree is usually used as the weak learner in gradient boosting, in recent years there has been a fast-growing trend to use decision table [15] as an intriguing alternative [16, 17, 18, 19]. Many works [16, 17, 20, 21] have shown that gradient boosted decision tables yields promising performance on various tasks and achieves great inference efficiency over generic decision trees. In addition, some famous open-source gradient boosting libraries [22, 17] have also recently provided the support for using decision table as the weak learner in gradient boosting.

As demonstrated in Fig. 2, a D𝐷D-dimensional decision table at a high level consists of D𝐷D Boolean tests and 2Dsuperscript2𝐷2^{D} output values. It can also be treated as a special full binary decision tree, called oblivious tree. In contrast with generic decision tree which has different Boolean tests at different internal nodes at the same level, the internal nodes at the same level of an oblivious tree share the same Boolean test defined with the same feature and threshold. Despite the similarly equivalent tree structure, it is worth noting that the algorithm for training oblivious tree is different from that for generic decision tree [23, 24]. Specifically, decision trees are typically trained through recursive algorithms [23, 24], while decision tables are trained through iterative algorithms following the top-down construction [15, 16]. Given tree depth D𝐷D, the shape of a generic decision tree is uncertain because it needs to process samples associated with the current node to determine whether to split this node. In contrast, we can not recursively build a decision table because all the samples in the dataset need to be processed to select the optimal split for each level of the decision table. Besides, given depth D𝐷D, the shape of an oblivious tree is fixed and the number of operations like node splitting and output value calculation is also fixed. In addition, the inference process on an oblivious tree is also different from that on a generic decision tree[16, 18] (see Section 3.1 for more detailed discussion).

In the literature, while there have been several studies on privacy-preserving VFL with gradient boosted decision trees (GBDT) [10, 8, 7], no prior work has explored privacy-preserving VFL with gradient boosted decision tables. As mentioned above, even training and inference on decision table are different from the case of generic decision tree, not to mention gradient boosting with decision table as the weak learner in the VFL setting. Therefore, these prior works cannot be directly applied to support privacy-preserving training and inference of gradient boosted decision tables in VFL. In addition, it is noted that these prior works are also confronted with limitations such as exposing sensitive intermediate results (e.g., sum of gradients) [10, 7], supporting training only among two participants [8] (see Section 2 for more detailed discussion).

In light of the above, we propose Privet, which, to our best knowledge, is the first system framework enabling privacy-preserving VFL service for training gradient boosted decision tables over distributed datasets. Privet ambitiously supports an arbitrary number of participants to collaboratively train gradient boosted decision tables, while allowing them to keep their data locally and offering strong protection on the sensitive intermediate outputs throughout the training process. Privet builds on lightweight secret sharing techniques to develop customized protocols securely realizing the key components required by training gradient boosted decision tables in the VFL setting.

Specifically, through an in-depth examination on the training process of gradient boosted decision tables, we manage to decompose the holistic secure design in the VFL setting into the design of a series of secure components run in a distributed manner among the participants, including secure node splitting, secure Sigmoid evaluation, secure discretization, and secure distributed decision table inference. The delicate synergy of these secure components leads to the holistic protocol of Privet for privately training gradient boosted decision tables in the VFL setting. Through the customized secure protocol, Privet outputs gradient boosted decision tables that are distributed among the involved participants, where each participant only holds a part of the model. Subsequently, secure inference on the ensemble of learned decision tables can also be well supported in a distributed manner among the participants. We implement and evaluate Privet’s protocols extensively over several real-world datasets as well as synthetic datasets. The results demonstrate that Privet presents promising performance in computation and communication. Meanwhile, the utility of the trained models in Privet is comparable to that in the plaintext centralized learning setting.

We highlight our contributions as follows.

  • •

    We present Privet, which, to our best knowledge, is the first system framework enabling privacy-preserving VFL service for gradient boosted decision tables. Privet allows an arbitrary number of participants holding vertically partitioned distributed datasets to securely train gradient boosted decision tables in a distributed manner, offering strong protection for sensitive individual data as well as for intermediate outputs.

  • •

    We devise a series of tailored secure components based on lightweight secret sharing techniques that run in a distributed manner among multiple participants with promising efficiency and utility, catering for the computation required by securely training gradient boosted decision tables in the VFL setting.

  • •

    We make an implementation of the proposed protocols and conduct an extensive evaluation over three real-world public datasets and three synthetic datasets. The experiment results demonstrate that Privet has promising performance, achieving model utility comparable to plaintext centralized learning.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 discusses the related work. Section 3 introduces some preliminaries. Section 4 gives a system overview. Section 5 presents the design of Privet. The security analysis is presented in Section 6, followed by the experiments in Section 7. Section 8 concludes the whole paper.

2 Related Work

Securely learning gradient boosted decision trees under HFL. Due to the problems of data isolation and data privacy, FL has emerged as a new privacy-preserving machine learning paradigm. Several existing works [5, 25, 6] have been focused on privacy-preserving gradient boosted decision trees (GBDT) under the HFL setting, which assume that data are horizontally partitioned between participants. Among them, the work [6] rely on use of secure aggregation and differential privacy to provide a privacy guarantee. The work [25] leverages secure hardware[26] to build private GBDT under HFL. Different from these works, our work targets privacy-preserving gradient boosting systems under the VFL setting.

Securely learning gradient boosted decision trees under VFL. To cater for the need to collaboratively build models between different organizations that hold data on the same set of samples but for different features, VFL has received increasing attention in recent years. The works [10, 8, 7] consider vertical federated gradient boosted decision trees, which are most related to ours. In particular, SecureBoost [10] is the first work on privacy-preserving GBDT over vertically partitioned data, which uses homomorphic encryption to preserve data privacy. However, it has limited security guarantee because intermediate information (e.g., the sum of gradients in a bucket) is revealed during the training process. Moreover, homomorphic encryption involves heavy cryptographic operations and requires large memory, which results in low training efficiency. The works[8, 7] improve SecureBoost [10] in terms of efficiency via multi-party computation (MPC) techniques. Specifically, the work [8] proposes a secure GBDT system leveraging the additive secret sharing technique [27]. However, their proposed system is only designed for the two-party setting. Xie et al. [7] deal with the issue to support secure multi-party training. However, since they adopt large-scale matrix multiplication in the secret sharing domain to discretize secret-shared gradients into buckets, their scheme requires more communication and computation overhead compared to [8]. Moreover, the design in [7] has notable privacy leakages, e.g., the intermediate inference results of all training samples are leaked to the participant who holds the label set because it relies on this participant to conduct inference.

We also note that all these works [10, 8, 7] are aimed at supporting secure training and inference for gradient boosting with generic decision trees under VFL. In recent years, the gradient boosted decision table technique has seen rapidly growing adoption in various applications, such as learning to rank (LTR) [18, 21, 28], recommendation systems[16, 29], and medical diagnosis [30, 31]. Although the training of decision tree and decision table has some similarities, e.g., both of them need permutation protocols, their learning algorithms are different inherently. Thus the works [10, 8, 7] cannot directly support secure gradient boosting over decision tables under VFL. In comparison with them, Privet focuses on securely supporting privacy-preserving VFL for gradient boosted decision tables. In addition, Privet departs from them by achieving comparable utility to plaintext, concealing intermediate information for strong privacy, and supporting an arbitrary number of participants.

Secure decision tree learning supporting both horizontally and vertically partitioned data. There are some works [32, 33, 34] which can support secure decision tree learning on both horizontally and vertically partitioned data in an outsourcing setting. Specifically, the work [32] considers a setting where data owners secret-share all their data among three servers and designs a protocol to enable the three servers to securely perform an adapted C4.5 decision tree learning algorithm. The work [34] proposes protocols to train decision trees for the Random Forest model, which similarly considers a setting where the data owners secret-share all their data among two extra non-colluding computing parties. In [33], Deforth et al. focus on building private gradient boosted decision trees and consider a scenario where data owners secret-share their data among a set of computing parties which may also be an extra set of servers. In contrast with these works that outsource the data and computation, Privet does not require such an extra set of non-colluding servers which may not be an easy assumption to meet in practice. Meanwhile, Privet allows the raw data of each participant to stay local throughout the whole training process, fitting the salient feature of FL.

3 Preliminaries

3.1 Decision Table

Consider a dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} consisting of N𝑁N samples {𝐱i,yi}subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖\{\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i}\} for i=0,⋯,N−1𝑖0⋯𝑁1i=0,\cdots,N-1, where 𝐱i=(xi​1,⋯,xi​J)subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1⋯subscript𝑥𝑖𝐽\mathbf{x}_{i}=(x_{i1},\cdots,x_{iJ}) is a J𝐽J-dimensional tuple and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is the label of the i𝑖i-th sample. The j𝑗j-th element of 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} is the value of an input attribute Xjsubscript𝑋𝑗X_{j}. A D𝐷D-dimensional decision table consists of D𝐷D Boolean tests and 2Dsuperscript2𝐷2^{D} output values. A Boolean test is of the form Xj<tsubscript𝑋𝑗𝑡X_{j}<t, which outputs 111 if the j𝑗j-th element in a given input tuple is less than a threshold t𝑡t and 00 otherwise.

As illustrated in Fig. 2, a D𝐷D-dimensional decision table is equivalent to a full binary tree with D+1𝐷1D+1 levels, where each internal node from the 00-th level (for the root node) to the (D−1)𝐷1(D-1)-th level has a Boolean test; each edge is assigned the outcome of its source node’s test and each leaf node at the D𝐷D-th level is associated with an output value. Such equivalent tree is called oblivious tree, because all internal nodes at the same level share the same test, as opposed to generic decision trees that have different tests at the same level. More specifically, the test at the d𝑑d-th level of an oblivious tree could be represented as Fd<tdsubscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑡𝑑F_{d}<t_{d}, where d∈[0,D−1]𝑑0𝐷1d\in[0,D-1], the split feature Fd∈{X1,⋯,XJ}subscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑋1⋯subscript𝑋𝐽F_{d}\in\{X_{1},\cdots,X_{J}\}, and tdsubscript𝑡𝑑t_{d} is the split threshold. The special structure of oblivious tree results in its different training and inference methods from non-oblivious trees like CART [23]. In [15], Kohavi et al. first introduce a top-down construction of oblivious trees and use information gain as the evaluation metric to find the optimal test at each level. Different evaluation metrics are used in later studies, like mean squared error (MSE)[16] and Newton’s method[17].

We follow the top-down construction in [15, 16] to train oblivious trees. Algorithm 1 shows the process of training an oblivious tree, which produces D𝐷D tests and 2Dsuperscript2𝐷2^{D} output values. The learning algorithm starts from the 00-th level and builds an oblivious tree level by level iteratively. Given a test Xj<tsubscript𝑋𝑗𝑡X_{j}<t, we define 𝒟Xj<t={(𝐱,y)∈𝒟∣𝐱​(Xj)<t}subscript𝒟subscript𝑋𝑗𝑡conditional-set𝐱𝑦𝒟𝐱subscript𝑋𝑗𝑡\mathcal{D}_{X_{j}<t}=\left\{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\mathcal{D}\mid\mathbf{x}\left(X_{j}\right)<t\right\}, 𝒟Xj≥t=𝒟\𝒟Xj<tsubscript𝒟subscript𝑋𝑗𝑡\𝒟subscript𝒟subscript𝑋𝑗𝑡\mathcal{D}_{X_{j}\geq t}=\mathcal{D}\backslash\mathcal{D}_{X_{j}<t}. We also apply this notation to subsets 𝒱⊆𝒟𝒱𝒟\mathcal{V}\subseteq\mathcal{D}. Let 𝒮lsuperscript𝒮𝑙\mathcal{S}^{l} denote the set of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}’s subsets at the l𝑙l-th level, where l∈[0,D]𝑙0𝐷l\in[0,D]. At level 00, the training dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is associated with the root node and 𝒮0={𝒟}superscript𝒮0𝒟\mathcal{S}^{0}=\{\mathcal{D}\} (line 3). Once an optimal test F0<t0subscript𝐹0subscript𝑡0F_{0}<t_{0} at this level is found through the routine 𝖿𝗂𝗇𝖽​_​𝗌𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖿𝗂𝗇𝖽_𝗌𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{find\_split} (line 6), 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is partitioned into two subsets 𝒟F0<t0,𝒟F0≥t0subscript𝒟subscript𝐹0subscript𝑡0subscript𝒟subscript𝐹0subscript𝑡0\mathcal{D}_{F_{0}<t_{0}},\mathcal{D}_{F_{0}\geq t_{0}} according to it. After that, 𝒟F0<t0,𝒟F0≥t0subscript𝒟subscript𝐹0subscript𝑡0subscript𝒟subscript𝐹0subscript𝑡0\mathcal{D}_{F_{0}<t_{0}},\mathcal{D}_{F_{0}\geq t_{0}} are added to 𝒮1superscript𝒮1\mathcal{S}^{1} (𝒮1={𝒟F0<t0,𝒟F0≥t0}superscript𝒮1subscript𝒟subscript𝐹0subscript𝑡0subscript𝒟subscript𝐹0subscript𝑡0\mathcal{S}^{1}=\{\mathcal{D}_{F_{0}<t_{0}},\mathcal{D}_{F_{0}\geq t_{0}}\}) and a new level is created (lines 9-10).

At level 111, an optimal test F1<t1subscript𝐹1subscript𝑡1F_{1}<t_{1} is found and 𝒟F0<t0,𝒟F0≥t0subscript𝒟subscript𝐹0subscript𝑡0subscript𝒟subscript𝐹0subscript𝑡0\mathcal{D}_{F_{0}<t_{0}},\mathcal{D}_{F_{0}\geq t_{0}} are each partitioned into two subsets according to F1<t1subscript𝐹1subscript𝑡1F_{1}<t_{1}. The same procedure is repeated until all the D𝐷D tests are learned. In this way, the tree structure is kept full and symmetric, and we have |𝒮l|=2lsuperscript𝒮𝑙superscript2𝑙|\mathcal{S}^{l}|=2^{l} at level l𝑙l, where each set in 𝒮lsuperscript𝒮𝑙\mathcal{S}^{l} is associated with a node at this level. When reaching the D𝐷D-th level, the output values will be calculated for the leaf nodes. Finally, an oblivious tree composed of D𝐷D tests and 2Dsuperscript2𝐷2^{D} output values is learned.

The optimal test at each level is found via the routine 𝖿𝗂𝗇𝖽​_​𝗌𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖿𝗂𝗇𝖽_𝗌𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{find\_split} by evaluating the candidate tests. Evaluation of the candidate tests can be made through different metrics. In Privet, we follow the popular second-order approximation method [35, 17] to evaluate tests because the decision tables in our work are trained sequentially for a gradient boosting system. Besides, the output values of decision tables can also be calculated following the gradient boosting theory, which will be introduced shortly in Section 3.2.

As presented in Algorithm 1, training a decision table (oblivious tree) is an iterative process, while decision trees are typically trained through recursive algorithms[23, 24]. Given tree depth D𝐷D, the shape of a generic decision tree is uncertain because it needs to process samples associated with the current node to judge whether to split this node. However, the shape of an oblivious tree is predetermined at a given dimension D𝐷D. To select the optimal split at each level, all the samples in the dataset are required to be processed. Besides, the number of operations involved in training an oblivious tree, such as 𝖿𝗂𝗇𝖽​_​𝗌𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖿𝗂𝗇𝖽_𝗌𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{find\_split} and output value calculation, is fixed.

Decision table outperforms generic decision tree in inference efficiency significantly. As illustrated in Fig. 2, each leaf node of an oblivious tree (the right sub-figure in Fig. 2) corresponds to a Boolean sequence and the comparisons required by D𝐷D tests could be parallelized. In contrast, inference in a regular decision tree is made by traversing the tree from the root node to a leaf node, which means the direction of the inference path after the current node depends on the test result of this node. Note that while the evaluation of each decision node in generic decision tree inference can be parallelized, it is still necessary to traverse the tree from the root node sequentially so as to identify the correct leaf node that produces the inference result. For example, as shown in the left sub-figure in Fig. 2, even if we parallelize the evaluation of each decision node, i.e., we obtain the sequence of test results [0,0,1,1,0]00110[0,0,1,1,0] by evaluating the 00-th split to the 444-th split simultaneously, we cannot directly identify which leaf node is finally chosen using [0,0,1,1,0]00110[0,0,1,1,0]. On the contrary, decision table inference is free of such sequential traversal [16, 17, 18]. As illustrated in the right sub-figure in Fig. 2, once the sequence comprised of Boolean test result at each level is obtained, the inference result can be immediately obtained because this Boolean sequence is also the identifier of a leaf node.

Additionally, it is noted that in gradient boosting systems, the number, size, and depth of generic decision trees are not necessarily smaller than decision tables when achieving the same accuracy because they are both weak learners and only require weak predictability. As reported in prior work [16], compared with gradient boosted decision trees with the number of trees T=50𝑇50T=50 and tree depth D=7𝐷7D=7, gradient boosted decision tables only requires depth D=6𝐷6D=6 given the same number of oblivious trees T=50𝑇50T=50 to achieve similar accuracy performance. Furthermore, it is noted that with the same depth D𝐷D, a decision table only needs storage of D𝐷D decision nodes (one for each level), while a generic decision tree may require storage of up to 2D−1superscript2𝐷12^{D}-1 decision nodes [16, 18].

3.2 Gradient Boosted Decision Tables

A gradient boosting system is built by training a set of weak learners sequentially based on the boosting algorithm[35, 36]. For the given dataset 𝒟={𝐱i,yi}i=0N−1𝒟subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑁1𝑖0\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i}\}^{N-1}_{i=0}, a gradient boosting system sums the inference results of T𝑇T weak learners to produce the ultimate inference result for the i𝑖i-th sample[36]: y^i(T)=∑t=1Tft​(𝐱i)superscriptsubscript^𝑦𝑖𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝐱𝑖\hat{y}_{i}^{(T)}=\sum_{t=1}^{T}f_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{i}), where ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t} corresponds to the model of the t𝑡t-th weak learner. In gradient boosted decision tables[16, 17], ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t} corresponds to a decision table. A given sample will be classified into the leaf nodes in the decision tables according to the tests in them. Its ultimate inference result is calculated by summing up the output values associated with the corresponding leaf nodes.

The essence of gradient boosting algorithm comes from how it boosts the weak learners sequentially. After training t−1𝑡1t-1 weak learners, the t𝑡t-th model ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t} is needed to be trained and added to minimize the following objective function[35]:

=∑i=0N−1l​(yi,y^i(t−1)+ft​(𝐱i))+Ω​(ft),absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑁1𝑙subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript^𝑦𝑖𝑡1subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝐱𝑖Ωsubscript𝑓𝑡\displaystyle=\sum_{i=0}^{N-1}l(y_{i},\hat{y}_{i}^{(t-1)}+f_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{i}))+\Omega(f_{t}),

where l𝑙l is a twice differentiable convex loss function that takes yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}, y^i(t)superscriptsubscript^𝑦𝑖𝑡\hat{y}_{i}^{(t)} as input, and outputs the loss. Typically, for regression problems, MSE is used as the loss function and the gradients are calculated as follows: gi=y^i−yisubscript𝑔𝑖subscript^𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖g_{i}=\hat{y}_{i}-y_{i} and hi=1subscriptℎ𝑖1h_{i}=1[16, 7]. When the problem is classification, a common choice is logistic loss and the gradients are calculated as follows: gi=pi−yisubscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖g_{i}=p_{i}-y_{i} and hi=pi×(1−pi)subscriptℎ𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖1subscript𝑝𝑖h_{i}=p_{i}\times(1-p_{i}), where pi=𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽​(y^i)subscript𝑝𝑖𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽subscript^𝑦𝑖p_{i}=\mathsf{Sigmoid}(\hat{y}_{i})[37]. For a value x∈ℝ𝑥ℝ{x}\in\mathbb{R}, the Sigmoid function is: 𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽​(x)=1/(1+e−x)𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽𝑥11superscript𝑒𝑥\mathsf{Sigmoid}({x})=1/(1+e^{-x}). For the leaf node k𝑘k, which is associated with a subset 𝒱k⊂𝒟superscript𝒱𝑘𝒟\mathcal{V}^{k}\subset\mathcal{D}, we define ℐk={i|(𝐱i,yi)∈𝒱k}superscriptℐ𝑘conditional-set𝑖subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝒱𝑘\mathcal{I}^{k}=\{i|(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})\in\mathcal{V}^{k}\} as its index set. This notation is also used to denote the index set associated with the internal node, e.g., we write ℐqsuperscriptℐ𝑞\mathcal{I}^{q} for node q𝑞q. Then, after removing the constant terms, Eq. 1 can be rewritten as[35]:

ℒ~(t)superscript~ℒ𝑡\displaystyle\tilde{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)} =∑k=0L−1[(∑i∈ℐkgi)​wk+12​(∑i∈ℐkhi+λ)​wk2]+γ​Labsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐿1delimited-[]subscript𝑖superscriptℐ𝑘subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘12subscript𝑖superscriptℐ𝑘subscriptℎ𝑖𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘2𝛾𝐿\displaystyle=\sum_{k=0}^{L-1}[(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}^{k}}g_{i})w_{k}+\frac{1}{2}(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}^{k}}h_{i}+\lambda)w_{k}^{2}]+\gamma L (2)

where wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} is the output value associated with the leaf node k𝑘k, L𝐿L is the number of leaf nodes in the tree, and λ,γ𝜆𝛾\lambda,\gamma are hyper-parameters to control the regularization. When the tree stops growing, wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} and the minimum loss of the current tree are calculated by [35]:

wk=−∑i∈ℐkgi∑i∈ℐkhi+λ,subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑖superscriptℐ𝑘subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑖superscriptℐ𝑘subscriptℎ𝑖𝜆w_{k}=-\frac{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}^{k}}g_{i}}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}^{k}}h_{i}+\lambda}, (3)
ℒ~(t)superscript~ℒ𝑡\displaystyle\tilde{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)} =−12​∑k=0L−1(∑i∈ℐkgi)2∑i∈ℐkhi+λ+γ​L,absent12superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐿1superscriptsubscript𝑖superscriptℐ𝑘subscript𝑔𝑖2subscript𝑖superscriptℐ𝑘subscriptℎ𝑖𝜆𝛾𝐿\displaystyle=-\frac{1}{2}\sum_{k=0}^{L-1}\frac{(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}^{k}}g_{i})^{2}}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}^{k}}h_{i}+\lambda}+\gamma L, (4)

Eq. 4 can be used as the impurity function for evaluating the tests. In Privet, we follow the above theory to find optimal tests in decision table. Suppose we have learned b𝑏b tests from the level 00 to the level (b−1)𝑏1(b-1) of a D𝐷D-dimensional decision table and we need to find an optimal test at level b𝑏b. The nodes at the b𝑏b-th level are numbered from 00 to 2b−1superscript2𝑏12^{b}-1 and the q𝑞q-th node is associated with an index set ℐqsuperscriptℐ𝑞\mathcal{I}^{q}. A candidate test Xj<tsubscript𝑋𝑗𝑡X_{j}<t will split the 2bsuperscript2𝑏2^{b} nodes at this level into 2b+1superscript2𝑏12^{b+1} nodes. Among all the candidate tests, the optimal test is the test that has the minimum score. The definition of score is defined as[38]:

S​c​o​r​e=∑q=02b−1(𝒫ℐLq+𝒫ℐRq),𝑆𝑐𝑜𝑟𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑞0superscript2𝑏1subscript𝒫superscriptsubscriptℐ𝐿𝑞subscript𝒫superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑅𝑞\displaystyle Score=\sum_{q=0}^{2^{b}-1}\left(\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{I}_{L}^{q}}+\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{I}_{R}^{q}}\right), (5)

where

𝒫ℐ=−12​(∑i∈ℐgi)2∑i∈ℐhi+λsubscript𝒫ℐ12superscriptsubscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝑔𝑖2subscript𝑖ℐsubscriptℎ𝑖𝜆\displaystyle\quad\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{I}}=-\frac{1}{2}\frac{\left(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}g_{i}\right)^{2}}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}h_{i}+\lambda} (6)

is the impurity of a node and ℐLq,ℐRqsuperscriptsubscriptℐ𝐿𝑞superscriptsubscriptℐ𝑅𝑞\mathcal{I}_{L}^{q},\mathcal{I}_{R}^{q} are the index sets associated with the q𝑞q-th node’s left and right child nodes after the split respectively.

3.3 Additive Secret Sharing

In Privet, we use n𝑛n-out-of-n𝑛n additive secret sharing over ℤ2Qsubscriptℤsuperscript2𝑄\mathbb{Z}_{2^{Q}}, where Q𝑄Q denotes the number of bits for value representation. In such secret sharing, a secret value x∈ℤ2Q𝑥subscriptℤsuperscript2𝑄x\in\mathbb{Z}_{2^{Q}} is additively split into n𝑛n secret shares ⟨x⟩1,⟨x⟩2,⋯,⟨x⟩n∈ℤ2Qsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥2⋯subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥𝑛subscriptℤsuperscript2𝑄\langle x\rangle_{1},\langle x\rangle_{2},\cdots,\langle x\rangle_{n}\in\mathbb{Z}_{2^{Q}} such that ⟦x⟧=⟨x⟩1+⟨x⟩2+⋯+⟨x⟩n\llbracket x\rrbracket=\langle x\rangle_{1}+\langle x\rangle_{2}+\cdots+\langle x\rangle_{n} mod 2Qsuperscript2𝑄\;2^{Q}. The n𝑛n shares are held by n𝑛n parties respectively to be engaged in a secure computation. For simplicity, we denote such additive secret sharing of x𝑥x by ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket. Below we introduce the basic operations related to additive secret sharing in the n𝑛n-party setting.

∙𝖲𝗁𝖺𝗋𝗂𝗇𝗀∙absent𝖲𝗁𝖺𝗋𝗂𝗇𝗀\bullet\mathsf{Sharing}: To additively share a private value x𝑥x of party Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}, Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} needs to generate n−1𝑛1n-1 random numbers {xm≠l},m∈[1,n]subscript𝑥𝑚𝑙𝑚1𝑛\{x_{m\neq l}\},m\in[1,n] over ℤ2Qsubscriptℤsuperscript2𝑄\mathbb{Z}_{2^{Q}} and sends xm≠lsubscript𝑥𝑚𝑙x_{m\neq l} to Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l}, respectively. Then Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} holds ⟨x⟩l=(x−∑p=1,p≠lnxp)subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥𝑙𝑥superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequence𝑝1𝑝𝑙𝑛subscript𝑥𝑝\langle x\rangle_{l}=(x-\sum_{p=1,p\neq l}^{n}x_{p})\;mod 2Qsuperscript2𝑄\;2^{Q} and Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l} holds ⟨x⟩m≠l=xm≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥𝑚𝑙subscript𝑥𝑚𝑙\langle x\rangle_{m\neq l}=x_{m\neq l}, respectively, as a share of x𝑥x. For conciseness, the modulo operation will be henceforth omitted in the following protocols.

∙𝖱𝖾𝖼𝗈𝗇𝗌𝗍𝗋𝗎𝖼𝗍𝗂𝗈𝗇∙absent𝖱𝖾𝖼𝗈𝗇𝗌𝗍𝗋𝗎𝖼𝗍𝗂𝗈𝗇\bullet\mathsf{Reconstruction}: To reconstruct (𝖱𝖾𝖼​(⋅)𝖱𝖾𝖼⋅\mathsf{Rec(\cdot)}) a shared value ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket on Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}, Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l} sends its share ⟨x⟩m≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥𝑚𝑙\langle x\rangle_{m\neq l} to Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} and Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} computes ∑p=1n⟨x⟩psuperscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑛subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥𝑝\sum_{p=1}^{n}\langle x\rangle_{p}.

∙𝖠𝖽𝖽𝗂𝗍𝗂𝗈𝗇∙absent𝖠𝖽𝖽𝗂𝗍𝗂𝗈𝗇\bullet\mathsf{Addition}: For the two secret-shared values ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket and ⟦y⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑦\llbracket y\rrbracket , to securely compute addition (⟦z⟧=⟦x⟧+⟦y⟧\llbracket z\rrbracket=\llbracket x\rrbracket+\llbracket y\rrbracket), each participant Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} locally computes ⟨z⟩m=⟨x⟩m+⟨y⟩msubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑧𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑦𝑚\langle z\rangle_{m}=\langle x\rangle_{m}+\langle y\rangle_{m}. Similarly, to compute subtraction (⟦z⟧=⟦x⟧−⟦y⟧)\llbracket z\rrbracket=\llbracket x\rrbracket-\llbracket y\rrbracket), each participant subtracts its local share of y𝑦y from that of x𝑥x.

∙𝖬𝗎𝗅𝗍𝗂𝗉𝗅𝗂𝖼𝖺𝗍𝗂𝗈𝗇∙absent𝖬𝗎𝗅𝗍𝗂𝗉𝗅𝗂𝖼𝖺𝗍𝗂𝗈𝗇\bullet\mathsf{Multiplication}: To multiply a secret-shared value ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket with a constant c𝑐c (⟦z⟧=c×⟦x⟧\llbracket z\rrbracket=c\times{\llbracket x\rrbracket}), each participant multiplies its local share of x𝑥x by c𝑐c. To multiply two secret-shared values ⟦x⟧,⟦y⟧\llbracket x\rrbracket,\llbracket y\rrbracket (denoted by ⟦z⟧=⟦x⟧×⟦y⟧\llbracket z\rrbracket=\llbracket x\rrbracket\times\llbracket y\rrbracket where z=x​y𝑧𝑥𝑦z=xy), the multiplication triple technique can be used [39]. In an offline phase, all parties obtain a secret-shared multiplication triple (⟦a⟧,⟦b⟧,⟦c⟧)(\llbracket a\rrbracket,\llbracket b\rrbracket,\llbracket c\rrbracket), where a,b𝑎𝑏a,b are uniformly random numbers in ℤ2Qsubscriptℤsuperscript2𝑄\mathbb{Z}_{2^{Q}} and c=a​b𝑐𝑎𝑏c=ab. The secret-shared triples are data-independent and can be prepared and distributed offline by an independent third-party [40], so hereafter we assume the triples are available for use in online secure computation among the parties. The secret-shared multiplication proceeds as follows. Each party Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} locally computes ⟨e⟩m=⟨x⟩m−⟨a⟩msubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑒𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎𝑚\langle e\rangle_{m}=\langle x\rangle_{m}-\langle a\rangle_{m} and ⟨f⟩m=⟨y⟩m−⟨b⟩msubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑓𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑦𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑏𝑚\langle f\rangle_{m}=\langle y\rangle_{m}-\langle b\rangle_{m}. After that, the parties run 𝖱𝖾𝖼(⟦e⟧),𝖱𝖾𝖼(⟦f⟧)\mathsf{Rec}(\llbracket e\rrbracket),\mathsf{Rec}(\llbracket f\rrbracket). Next, Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} computes ⟨z⟩m=j×e×f+f×⟨a⟩m+e×⟨b⟩m+⟨c⟩msubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑧𝑚𝑗𝑒𝑓𝑓subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎𝑚𝑒subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑏𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑐𝑚\langle z\rangle_{m}=j\times e\times f+f\times\langle a\rangle_{m}+e\times\langle b\rangle_{m}+\langle c\rangle_{m}, where j=1𝑗1j=1 if m=1𝑚1m=1 and j=0𝑗0j=0 if m≠1𝑚1m\neq 1. Table I summarizes the key notations in this paper.

4 System Overview

4.1 System Architecture

Fig. 3 illustrates the system architecture of Privet, which targets the vertical federated learning scenario. In Privet, multiple participants (e.g., business organizations and institutions) want to collaboratively train gradient boosted decision tables over vertically partitioned data. Under such setting, a dataset consisting of N𝑁N samples (each is associated with a feature vector and a label) is vertically partitioned among n𝑛n participants P1,P2,⋯,Pnsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2⋯subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n}. Each participant Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} holds its respective dataset 𝒟mN×Jm={𝐱iJm}i=0N−1subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑁subscript𝐽𝑚𝑚subscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐽𝑚𝑁1𝑖0\mathcal{D}^{N\times J_{m}}_{m}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}^{J_{m}}\}^{N-1}_{i=0}, where Jmsubscript𝐽𝑚J_{m} denotes the number of features owned by Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} and is subject to ∑m=1nJm=Jsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑛subscript𝐽𝑚𝐽\sum_{m=1}^{n}J_{m}=J, 𝐱iJmsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐽𝑚\mathbf{x}_{i}^{J_{m}} represents the i𝑖i-th sample of 𝒟mN×Jmsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑁subscript𝐽𝑚𝑚\mathcal{D}^{N\times J_{m}}_{m}. Let 𝐲={yi}i=0N−1𝐲subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑁1𝑖0\mathbf{y}=\{y_{i}\}^{N-1}_{i=0} be the set of sample labels. Following prior works on VFL [10, 7, 8], we consider two roles for the participants: active participant (AP) and passive participant (PP). In particular, there is one AP that holds a local dataset as well as the label set 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}; and the remaining participants are PPs, each only holding a local dataset. For simplicity, in Privet, we assume the participant Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n} is the AP.

Throughout the secure training process in Privet, each participant keeps its feature data locally. The Boolean tests and output values of the decision tables are securely learned in Privet, in such a manner that no participant knows the complete models. In particular, Privet follows a setting similar to the works [10, 7, 8, 11] under VFL, where each participant learns partial information of the learned models. Specifically, in Privet, all the participants know the split feature of each test in a decision table of the ensemble and who owns this feature, but only the participant owning this feature knows the split threshold of the test. Formally, for the learned test Fd<tdsubscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑡𝑑F_{d}<t_{d} at the d𝑑d-th level (d∈[0,D−1]𝑑0𝐷1d\in[0,D-1]) of the t𝑡t-th decision table (t∈[1,T]𝑡1𝑇t\in[1,T]) in the ensemble, the split feature Fdsubscript𝐹𝑑F_{d} is revealed to all participants but the threshold tdsubscript𝑡𝑑t_{d} is only known by the participant owing the feature data corresponding to Fdsubscript𝐹𝑑F_{d}. In addition, all the output values of leaf nodes are produced in secret-shared form among all participants.

4.2 Threat Model

Privet is designed under the semi-honest adversary model, as is common in state-of-the-art security designs on vertical federated learning [8, 41]. Specifically, in Privet, each participant is assumed to faithfully follow the protocol specification but may try to deduce other participants’ private information from the messages they receive. It is noted that though we consider two roles AP and PP for the participants, no additional trust is assumed regarding the AP. The semi-honest adversary model should be reasonable in practice because VFL aims at breaking down the data silos between business organizations, where the behavior of each organization is strictly enforced by privacy regulations[42]. We also consider that a static adversary may corrupt a subset of τ𝜏\tau participants (τ≤n−1𝜏𝑛1\tau\leq n-1). That is, a static adversary may choose a subset of the participants to corrupt before the VFL procedure and the chosen participants remain corrupted during the VFL procedure.

Under the above threat model, Privet aims to guarantee that a semi-honest participant individually cannot learn any other participant’s local data and learned partial model (tests and output values of each decision table in the ensemble) throughout the VFL procedure. In case of collusion among a subset of the participants, Privet strives to still ensure that the honest participants’ private information is protected against the corrupted participants. Like prior works [8, 32, 10], Privet does not hide the data-independent generic parameters, such as the dimension D𝐷D and the number of decision tables T𝑇T.

5 The Design of Privet

5.1 Overview

We provide in Algorithm 2 an overview of the secure training framework in Privet, which inputs the vertically partitioned datasets {𝒟mN×Jm}m=1nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑁subscript𝐽𝑚𝑚𝑛𝑚1\{\mathcal{D}^{N\times J_{m}}_{m}\}^{n}_{m=1} and the label set 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} from the participants, and outputs an ensemble ℰℰ\mathcal{E} of distributed decision tables among the participants. At the beginning, the secret-shared inference result ⟦𝐲^(0)⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript^𝐲0\llbracket{\mathbf{\hat{y}}^{(0)}}\rrbracket is initialized as the secret sharing ⟦𝟎N⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript0𝑁\llbracket\mathbf{0}_{N}\rrbracket (N𝑁N denotes the length of the secret-shared vector), and the AP distributes the secret shares of its label set to other participants. After that, T𝑇T distributed decision tables are securely built sequentially in T𝑇T rounds (lines 6-10).

We develop a secure decision table learning algorithm 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} to support the secure training of a single (distributed) decision table in each round. 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} consists of several secure components, including (i) secure node splitting 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit}, (ii) secure Sigmoid evaluation 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽\mathsf{SecSigmoid}, and (iii) secure discretization 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc}. The secure node splitting component 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit} (Section 5.2.1) is to securely split the nodes at a certain level and partition the index sets associated with these nodes without revealing the partitioned index sets. The secure Sigmoid evaluation component 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽\mathsf{SecSigmoid} (Section 5.2.2) inputs a secret-shared value and calculates the Sigmoid function in the secret sharing domain. The secure discretization component 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} (Section 5.2.3) is to securely rearrange the secret-shared gradients according to the local permutations owned by each participant and then group them into buckets. Through the synergy of these components, 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} allows the participants to securely train a distributed decision table in each round, for which we will give the details in Section 5.2.4.

After securely training a distributed decision table in a certain round, secure inference needs to be conducted, of which the result will be added to previous inference results (line 9) for use in 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} in the next round. To this end, we develop a secure distributed decision table inference protocol 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} (Section 5.3), which inputs each participant’s local data and partial model to produce secret-shared inference results without leaking their data and partial model. It is worth noting that 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} can also be used to support secure inference for new data after the completion of the whole training process.

5.2 Secure Distributed Decision Table Training

5.2.1 Secure Node Splitting

An oblivious tree grows to a new level by splitting each node at the current level into two child nodes. In plaintext centralized decision table training (Algorithm 1), node splitting is performed by partitioning the samples associated with the node to be split. However, in VFL, the partitioning of samples must be revealed to all participants because the training dataset is vertically partitioned and all participants hold the same samples. For instance, given a test “H​e​i​g​h​t<180𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡180Height<180”, the participant owning feature data of “H​e​i​g​h​t𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡Height” needs to tell other participants which samples are less than 180180180 and which samples are greater than 180180180, which will leak each sample’s range of “H​e​i​g​h​t𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡Height” and raise critical privacy concerns.

To avoid this leakage, we design a secure node splitting component 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit}. Inspired by existing works[41, 8, 7], we utilize indicator vectors to conduct secure node splitting for each level of the decision table. At a high level, Privet associates the k𝑘k-th node (k∈[0,2d−1]𝑘0superscript2𝑑1k\in[0,2^{d}-1]) at the d𝑑d-th level (d∈[0,D−1]𝑑0𝐷1d\in[0,D-1]) of the oblivious decision tree with a first-order gradient vector ⟦𝐠k,d⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝐠𝑘𝑑\llbracket\mathbf{g}^{k,d}\rrbracket and a second-order gradient vector ⟦𝐡k,d⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝐡𝑘𝑑\llbracket\mathbf{h}^{k,d}\rrbracket, each containing N𝑁N elements that are secret-shared among all participants P1,P2,⋯,Pnsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2⋯subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n}. If the i𝑖i-th sample is partitioned into this node, the i𝑖i-th element in ⟦𝐠k,d⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝐠𝑘𝑑\llbracket\mathbf{g}^{k,d}\rrbracket and ⟦𝐡k,d⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝐡𝑘𝑑\llbracket\mathbf{h}^{k,d}\rrbracket will be set as the i𝑖i-th sample’s first and second-order gradients, respectively, otherwise the i𝑖i-th element will be set as ⟦0⟧delimited-⟦⟧0\llbracket 0\rrbracket.

Algorithm 3 gives the procedure of secure node splitting. Firstly, participant Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} who owns the optimal test Fd<tdsubscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑡𝑑F_{d}<t_{d} at the d𝑑d-th level locally generates left indicator vector 𝐯lsubscript𝐯𝑙\mathbf{v}_{l} and right indicator vector 𝐯rsubscript𝐯𝑟\mathbf{v}_{r} and then distributes their secret sharings (denoted by ⟦𝐯l⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐯𝑙\llbracket\mathbf{v}_{l}\rrbracket and ⟦𝐯r⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐯𝑟\llbracket\mathbf{v}_{r}\rrbracket) to other participants (i.e., lines 3-10 in Algorithm 3). Upon receiving ⟦𝐯l⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐯𝑙\llbracket\mathbf{v}_{l}\rrbracket and ⟦𝐯r⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐯𝑟\llbracket\mathbf{v}_{r}\rrbracket, for the k𝑘k-th node at this level, P1,P2,⋯,Pnsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2⋯subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n} update the first-order and second-order gradient vector of the k𝑘k-th node’s left and right child nodes. The update is achieved with secure element-wise multiplication between secret-shared indicator vectors and gradient vectors (i.e., lines 11-16 in Algorithm 3). In this way, the index set processed by each node is hidden and the number of the samples processed by each node remains constant as N𝑁N, which means an adversary cannot deduce any information from node splitting.

5.2.2 Secure Sigmoid Evaluation

There are mainly two challenges in securely calculating the Sigmoid function in the secret sharing domain. Firstly, how to compute the division ⟦xy⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥𝑦\llbracket\frac{x}{y}\rrbracket given two secret-shared values ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket and ⟦y⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑦\llbracket y\rrbracket? Secondly, how to compute the exponentiation function ⟦ex⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝑒𝑥\llbracket e^{x}\rrbracket given a secret-shared value ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket? Next, we introduce how Privet tackles the two challenges so as to allow the participants to securely calculate the Sigmoid function in the secret sharing domain. For the first challenge, we introduce a secure division component 𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏\mathsf{SDiv} by transforming the division calculation into a numerical optimization problem. Specifically, we note that the core obstacle of calculating ⟦xy⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥𝑦\llbracket\frac{x}{y}\rrbracket given ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket and ⟦y⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑦\llbracket y\rrbracket is to calculate the secret-shared reciprocal ⟦1y⟧delimited-⟦⟧1𝑦\llbracket\frac{1}{y}\rrbracket. Therefore, we first approximate 1y1𝑦\frac{1}{y} by the iterative Newton-Raphson algorithm [43], following previous works [44, 45]: zi←2​zi−1−y​zi−12←subscript𝑧𝑖2subscript𝑧𝑖1𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖12z_{i}\leftarrow 2z_{i-1}-yz_{i-1}^{2}, which will converge to zn≈1ysubscript𝑧𝑛1𝑦z_{n}\approx\frac{1}{y}. In Privet, we fix the initialization z0=1/Ysubscript𝑧01𝑌z_{0}=1/Y, where Y𝑌Y is a sufficiently large value. Note that the approximation consists of basic subtraction and multiplication operations which are naturally supported in the secret sharing domain, given ⟦y⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑦\llbracket y\rrbracket, the secret-shared reciprocal ⟦1y⟧delimited-⟦⟧1𝑦\llbracket\frac{1}{y}\rrbracket can be securely calculated. After securely calculating the reciprocal ⟦1y⟧delimited-⟦⟧1𝑦\llbracket\frac{1}{y}\rrbracket, Privet multiplies ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket by ⟦1y⟧delimited-⟦⟧1𝑦\llbracket\frac{1}{y}\rrbracket to obtain ⟦xy⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥𝑦\llbracket\frac{x}{y}\rrbracket, i.e., ⟦xy⟧=⟦x⟧⋅⟦1y⟧\llbracket\frac{x}{y}\rrbracket=\llbracket x\rrbracket\cdot\llbracket\frac{1}{y}\rrbracket.

For the second challenge, i.e., computing the exponentiation function ⟦ex⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝑒𝑥\llbracket e^{x}\rrbracket given a secret-shared value ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket, we approximate exsuperscript𝑒𝑥e^{x} by limit characterization, inspired by [44]: ex≈(1+x2n)2nsuperscript𝑒𝑥superscript1𝑥superscript2𝑛superscript2𝑛e^{x}\approx(1+\frac{x}{2^{n}})^{2^{n}}, which provides a good approximation of exsuperscript𝑒𝑥e^{x}. Note that since the approximation consists of basic addition and multiplication operations which are naturally supported in the secret sharing domain, given ⟦x⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑥\llbracket x\rrbracket, the secret-shared exponentiation ⟦ex⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝑒𝑥\llbracket e^{x}\rrbracket can be securely calculated. However, we note that the approximation method requires 2nsuperscript2𝑛2^{n} chain multiplications, and thus requires 2nsuperscript2𝑛2^{n} rounds of online communication. The approximation method is inefficient in practice since the communication complexity grows exponentially. Therefore, Privet further reduces the exponential communication complexity to linear communication complexity. More specifically, we note that the computation in the approximation can be regarded as a2nsuperscript𝑎superscript2𝑛a^{2^{n}} where a=1+x2n𝑎1𝑥superscript2𝑛a=1+\frac{x}{2^{n}}. Therefore, given ⟦a⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑎\llbracket a\rrbracket, Privet first securely calculates ⟦a2⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝑎2\llbracket a^{2}\rrbracket, which only requires one round of communication. After that, Privet regards the output as ⟦y⟧=⟦a2⟧\llbracket y\rrbracket=\llbracket a^{2}\rrbracket followed by securely calculating ⟦y2⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝑦2\llbracket y^{2}\rrbracket, which also only requires one round of communication. Therefore, in this way, we can securely calculate ⟦a2n⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝑎superscript2𝑛\llbracket a^{2^{n}}\rrbracket in log⁡2n=nsuperscript2𝑛𝑛\log 2^{n}=n rounds instead of 2nsuperscript2𝑛2^{n} rounds. Clearly, there is a trade-off between accuracy and efficiency in approximating exsuperscript𝑒𝑥e^{x} with (1+x2n)2nsuperscript1𝑥superscript2𝑛superscript2𝑛(1+\frac{x}{2^{n}})^{2^{n}} for computation in the secret sharing domain. In principle increasing the value of n𝑛n would lead to a more accurate approximation of the Sigmoid function. However, this also leads to increased computation and communication costs. Yet, as will be shown by our experiments, a small value of n𝑛n (in our case, we set n=2𝑛2n=2) suffices to enable Privet to achieve the accuracy comparable to plaintext centralized learning.

Remark. In the literature, there exist some methods for approximating the Sigmoid function so as to support secure Sigmoid evaluation, including Taylor expansion[46], piece-wise approximation [27], and function approximation like f​(x)=0.5​x1+|x|+0.5𝑓𝑥0.5𝑥1𝑥0.5f(x)=\frac{0.5x}{1+|x|}+0.5 [8]. For the Taylor expansion method, it requires a small input parameter (very close to 0), which is hard to satisfy in machine learning. The piece-wise approximation method has no such requirement but suffers from notable accuracy loss[8]. The work that is most closely related to ours is due to Fang et al. [8], who apply another function approximation method to approximate the Sigmoid function, i.e., f​(x)=0.5​x1+|x|+0.5𝑓𝑥0.5𝑥1𝑥0.5f(x)=\frac{0.5x}{1+|x|}+0.5. However, their method still experienced non-trivial loss in accuracy in their securely trained XGBoost model. As reported in their experiments, the Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC) value would go up to 0.84463 from 0.82945 if they replace the secure Sigmoid approximation with plaintext Sigmoid computation. In contrast, as will be shown by the experiments in Section 7.2, our proposed 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽\mathsf{SecSigmoid} can achieve AUC values that are highly close to those obtained using plaintext centralized learning (e.g., the gap can be as small as 0.0005).

5.2.3 Secure Discretization

Discretization, also called bucketing, is a commonly used grouping method in large-scale machine learning [35, 22]. Specifically, discretization groups the samples into a small number of buckets so as to allow the model training to scale on larger datasets. Let B𝐵B denote the number of buckets in discretization, where B≪Nmuch-less-than𝐵𝑁B\ll N and N𝑁N is the number of samples. In gradient boosting, gradients are grouped into buckets and the sum of gradients in each bucket is calculated in the training stage[35, 22]. Typically, for each feature, the gradients are first permuted by a permutation π𝜋\pi, which is obtained by sorting the values of this feature. Then the permuted gradients are partitioned into B𝐵B buckets. Obviously, the cost of training on B𝐵B buckets instead of N𝑁N samples can be greatly reduced.

However, discretization is non-trivial in privacy-preserving machine learning. In existing MPC-based works[34, 33, 32], the training data is secret-shared among a fixed set of computing servers, and sorting the secret-shared training data for discretization requires a large number of secure comparison operations, which is expensive in the secret sharing domain. In Privet, the training data is vertically partitioned, and thus the sorting process can be achieved locally to reduce the overhead. However, it is still difficult to permute the secret-shared gradient vector by a permutation π𝜋\pi held by a participant Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} without revealing π𝜋\pi to other participants.

To tackle the challenge, we propose a secure permutation algorithm 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm} (shown in Algorithm 4), which stems from the correlated randomness (CR) scheme in [8]. Our tailored design 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm} enables our secure discretization component 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} to outperform that in [8] in supporting an arbitrary number of participants. Fang et al. [8] design two MPC-based secure discretization methods. Specifically, they first propose a basic discretization method based on multiplications between secret-shared lagre-scale matrices. Then they obtain significant speedup over the basic method by utilizing CR to efficiently permute secret-shared gradients, and then group them. However, both the basic and improved methods in [8] only work under the two-party setting in VFL. The work [7] is the first MPC-based work supporting more than two participants in VFL with GBDT, but it simply follows the basic discretization method in [8]. In contrast, Privet tailors the improved discretization method from [8] to support an arbitrary number of participants, which is more efficient than the straightforward secret-shared lagre-scale matrix multiplication-based method from [7].

As shown in Algorithm 4, at the beginning of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm}, participants P1,P2,⋯,Pnsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2⋯subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n} hold a secret-shared vector ⟦𝐱⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐱\llbracket\mathbf{x}\rrbracket and Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} holds a permutation π𝜋\pi. At the end of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm}, participants P1,P2,⋯,Pnsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2⋯subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n} hold a secret-shared vector ⟦𝐮⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐮\llbracket\mathbf{u}\rrbracket where 𝐮=π​(𝐱)𝐮𝜋𝐱\mathbf{u}=\pi(\mathbf{x}). 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm} guarantees that except for Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}, other participants cannot know the permutation π𝜋\pi. In the initialization of Algorithm 4, all participants hold in advance the secret shares of πp​(𝐫)subscript𝜋𝑝𝐫\pi_{p}(\mathbf{r}) and 𝐫𝐫\mathbf{r}, and Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} additionally holds πpsubscript𝜋𝑝\pi_{p}. After the initialization, all participants collaboratively permute ⟦𝐱⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐱\llbracket\mathbf{x}\rrbracket in 222 rounds. In the first round, Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} generates the permutation πssubscript𝜋𝑠\pi_{s}, which subjects to π​(⋅)=πs​[πp​(⋅)]𝜋⋅subscript𝜋𝑠delimited-[]subscript𝜋𝑝⋅\pi(\cdot)=\pi_{s}[\pi_{p}(\cdot)], and then Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} sends πssubscript𝜋𝑠\pi_{s} to all other participants. After that, each participant Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} locally calculates ⟨𝐱⟩m−⟨𝐫⟩msubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐱𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐫𝑚\langle\mathbf{x}\rangle_{m}-\langle\mathbf{r}\rangle_{m}. In the second round, 𝐱−𝐫𝐱𝐫\mathbf{x-r} is revealed to Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}. Finally, the participants output ⟦𝐮⟧=⟦π(𝐱)⟧\llbracket\mathbf{u}\rrbracket=\llbracket\pi(\mathbf{x})\rrbracket ( i.e., lines 7-8 in Algorithm 4).

The correctness analysis of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm} is as follows:

𝐮𝐮\displaystyle\mathbf{u} =⟨𝐮⟩1+⟨𝐮⟩2+⋯+⟨𝐮⟩l+⋯+⟨𝐮⟩nabsentsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐮1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐮2⋯subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐮𝑙⋯subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐮𝑛\displaystyle=\langle\mathbf{u}\rangle_{1}+\langle\mathbf{u}\rangle_{2}+\cdots+\langle\mathbf{u}\rangle_{l}+\cdots+\langle\mathbf{u}\rangle_{n}
=πs​(⟨πp​(𝐫)⟩1)+πs​(⟨πp​(𝐫)⟩2)+⋯absentsubscript𝜋𝑠subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝜋𝑝𝐫1subscript𝜋𝑠subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝜋𝑝𝐫2⋯\displaystyle=\pi_{s}(\langle\pi_{p}(\mathbf{r})\rangle_{1})+\pi_{s}(\langle\pi_{p}(\mathbf{r})\rangle_{2})+\cdots
