Then, we introduce how Privet securely realizes discretization protocol 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} based on 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm}. At a high level, 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} first uses 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm} to securely permute the secret-shared first and second-order gradients of P1,P2,⋯,Pnsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2⋯subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n} with a permutation π𝜋\pi held by Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}, and then partitions the gradients into B𝐵B buckets. Algorithm 5 describes the details of our secure discretization protocol.

At the beginning, the secret-shared first and second-order gradient vectors ⟦𝐠⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐠\llbracket{\mathbf{g}}\rrbracket and ⟦𝐡⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐡\llbracket{\mathbf{h}}\rrbracket are securely permuted by 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm}, which outputs ⟦𝐠′⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝐠′\llbracket{\mathbf{g^{\prime}}}\rrbracket and ⟦𝐡′⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝐡′\llbracket{\mathbf{h^{\prime}}}\rrbracket. After that, P1,P2,⋯,Pnsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2⋯subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n} first initialize two secret-shared vectors ⟦𝜶⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝜶\llbracket\boldsymbol{\alpha}\rrbracket and ⟦𝜷⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝜷\llbracket\boldsymbol{\beta}\rrbracket of length B𝐵B to store the grouped first and second-order gradients, respectively. ⟦𝜶⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝜶\llbracket\boldsymbol{\alpha}\rrbracket and ⟦𝜷⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝜷\llbracket\boldsymbol{\beta}\rrbracket can be locally initialized as 𝟎Bsubscript0𝐵\mathbf{0}_{B}. After that, for b∈[0,B−1]𝑏0𝐵1b\in[0,B-1], the b𝑏b-th bucket’s secret-shared grouped first and second-order gradients ⟦𝜶b⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜶𝑏\llbracket\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{b}\rrbracket and ⟦𝜷b⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜷𝑏\llbracket\boldsymbol{\beta}_{b}\rrbracket are calculated as follows:

⟦𝜶b⟧=∑i=b×M(b+1)×M−1⟦𝐠i′⟧;⟦𝜷b⟧=∑i=b×M(b+1)×M−1⟦𝐡i′⟧,\llbracket\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{b}\rrbracket=\sum_{i=b\times M}^{(b+1)\times M-1}\llbracket\mathbf{g}^{\prime}_{i}\rrbracket;\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \llbracket\boldsymbol{\beta}_{b}\rrbracket=\sum_{i=b\times M}^{(b+1)\times M-1}\llbracket\mathbf{h}^{\prime}_{i}\rrbracket,

where M=N/B𝑀𝑁𝐵M=N/B is the number of gradients in a bucket. For conciseness, we assume that N𝑁N can divide B𝐵B evenly. As introduced in Section 5.2.1, since the invalid gradients are set as ⟦0⟧delimited-⟦⟧0\llbracket 0\rrbracket, the sum of the secret-shared gradients in a bucket is equal to that in the plaintext.

5.2.4 Secure Decision Table Training Algorithm

In this section, we introduce how Privet combines the components introduced above to securely train a distributed decision table. Algorithm 6 (named as 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable}) describes this process. 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} is the secure instantiation of Algorithm 1 and relies on the coordination of the secure components introduced above.

Algorithm 6 inputs the vertically partitioned datasets {𝒟mN×Jm}m=1nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑁subscript𝐽𝑚𝑚𝑛𝑚1\{\mathcal{D}^{N\times J_{m}}_{m}\}^{n}_{m=1}, secret-shared label ⟦𝐲⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐲\llbracket\mathbf{y}\rrbracket, and aggregated inference results ⟦𝐲^⟧delimited-⟦⟧^𝐲\llbracket\mathbf{\hat{y}}\rrbracket from the previous round of training, and then outputs a distributed decision table. The Boolean tests at different levels of the decision table are held by different participants and the output values associated with each leaf node are stored in an secret-shared vector ⟦𝐰⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐰\llbracket\mathbf{w}\rrbracket.

At the beginning of Algorithm 6, P1,P2,⋯,Pnsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2⋯subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n} calculate the secret-shared first and second-order gradient vectors (for the root node) (i.e., ⟦𝐠⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐠\llbracket\mathbf{g}\rrbracket and ⟦𝐡⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐡\llbracket\mathbf{h}\rrbracket at lines 3-8). After calculating the secret-shared gradients, Privet initializes a secret-shared vector ⟦𝐰⟧=⟦𝟎2D⟧\llbracket\mathbf{w}\rrbracket=\llbracket\mathbf{0}_{2^{D}}\rrbracket to store the 2Dsuperscript2𝐷2^{D} secret-shared output values. After that, a decision table will be built level by level. Similar to the functionality of 𝖿𝗂𝗇𝖽​_​𝗌𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖿𝗂𝗇𝖽_𝗌𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{find\_split} in Algorithm 1, Privet securely selects the optimal test Fd<tdsubscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑡𝑑F_{d}<t_{d} at the d𝑑d-th level (d∈[0,D−1]𝑑0𝐷1d\in[0,D-1]). Specifically, the selection is made greedily: the learning algorithm first selects the best test for each feature (i.e., lines 12-27) and then selects the optimal test among the J𝐽J selected candidate tests (i.e., lines 28-30). It is noted that the selection here is made following that in the plaintext domain, which is introduced in Section 3.2, and the operations in the selection are substituted with secure operations and proposed components. For the J𝐽J candidate tests, we initialize a secret-shared vector ⟦𝝈⟧=⟦𝟎J⟧\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket=\llbracket\mathbf{0}_{J}\rrbracket to store the score of each feature’s best test. Besides, Privet uses a public vector 𝜸=𝟎J𝜸subscript0𝐽\boldsymbol{\gamma}=\mathbf{0}_{J} to record the bucket ID of each feature’s best test.

For simplicity, the total J𝐽J features are numbered from 00 to J−1𝐽1J-1. At the beginning of the loop for the j𝑗j-th feature in Algorithm 6, the participant who holds the j𝑗j-th feature first generates a permutation πjsubscript𝜋𝑗\pi_{j} locally by sorting the values of the j𝑗j-th feature (denoted by 𝒟​(j)𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}(j)) in the ascending order, which will be used to securely permute the secret-shared gradient vectors associated with each node at this level. After that, a naive method is to permute the gradient vectors and then adapt the Exact Greedy Algorithm [35] to enumerate each training sample to find the best test. However, enumerating all training samples incurs heavy computation overhead. Moreover, it will incur prohibitively expensive communication overhead in the distributed setting, degrading the efficiency of the system.

We propose a component 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} (shown in Algorithm 5) to tackle this challenge and enable Privet to scale on larger datasets. Specifically, 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} inputs secret-shared gradient vectors ⟦𝐠k,d⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝐠𝑘𝑑\llbracket{\mathbf{g}^{k,d}}\rrbracket and ⟦𝐡k,d⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝐡𝑘𝑑\llbracket{\mathbf{h}^{k,d}}\rrbracket associated with the k𝑘k-th node at the d𝑑d-th level. The secret-shared gradients in ⟦𝐠k,d⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝐠𝑘𝑑\llbracket{\mathbf{g}^{k,d}}\rrbracket and ⟦𝐡k,d⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝐡𝑘𝑑\llbracket{\mathbf{h}^{k,d}}\rrbracket are securely discretized into B𝐵B buckets and stored in secret-shared vectors ⟦𝜶k,d⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝜶𝑘𝑑\llbracket\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{k,d}\rrbracket and ⟦𝜷k,d⟧delimited-⟦⟧superscript𝜷𝑘𝑑\llbracket\boldsymbol{\beta}^{k,d}\rrbracket, respectively. There are B−1𝐵1B-1 intervals among the B𝐵B buckets and each corresponds to a candidate test. In this way, Privet only needs to select the best test from B−1𝐵1B-1 candidate tests for each feature, instead of enumerating N𝑁N samples, so as to save considerable computation and communication cost. In Privet, we initialize a secret-shared vector ⟦𝜹⟧=⟦𝟎B−1⟧\llbracket\boldsymbol{\delta}\rrbracket=\llbracket\mathbf{0}_{B-1}\rrbracket for each feature to store the scores of the B−1𝐵1B-1 candidate tests.

After securely discretizing gradients into B𝐵B buckets, the B−1𝐵1B-1 candidate tests are evaluated to select the best test of the j𝑗j-th feature. For the c𝑐c-th candidate test (c∈[0,B−2]𝑐0𝐵2c\in[0,B-2]), the first c+1𝑐1c+1 buckets are aggregated to get ⟦Gl⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐺𝑙\llbracket{G_{l}}\rrbracket and ⟦Hl⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐻𝑙\llbracket{H_{l}}\rrbracket, which are the sum of gradients associated with the left child node, and the remaining B−c−1𝐵𝑐1B-c-1 buckets are aggregated to get ⟦Gr⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐺𝑟\llbracket{G_{r}}\rrbracket and ⟦Hr⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝐻𝑟\llbracket{H_{r}}\rrbracket, which are the sum of gradients associated with the right child node. The impurity of each node’s two child nodes is securely computed following Eq. 6 and then aggregated together to produce the secret-shared score of the c𝑐c-th candidate test following Eq. 5. The division needed in Eq. 6 can be securely calculated with our proposed secure component 𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏\mathsf{SDiv} in Section 5.2.2. Then for the j𝑗j-th feature, we will have B−1𝐵1B-1 secret-shared scores stored in ⟦𝜹⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝜹\llbracket\boldsymbol{\delta}\rrbracket.

After getting the B−1𝐵1B-1 scores, we need to select the best test that achieves the minimum score, which requires a method to securely calculate the index of the minimum value in a secret-shared vector. To tackle this challenge, Privet introduces a component 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇\mathsf{SecArgmin}, which inputs a secret-shared vector and outputs the index of the minimum value of the vector. It is noted that the key operation in the function Argmin is comparison, which is not naturally supported in the secret sharing domain. The secure comparison operation in our Privet is introduced as follows. Given two secret-shared values ⟦A⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐴\llbracket A\rrbracket and ⟦B⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐵\llbracket B\rrbracket, Privet first locally decomposes ⟦A−B⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐴𝐵\llbracket A-B\rrbracket into bits, and then inputs these bits into a parallel prefix adder (PPA) to securely compute the secret-shared most significant bit (MSB) of ⟦A−B⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐴𝐵\llbracket A-B\rrbracket, inspired by [47, 48]. After that, we convert the secret-shared MSB into the arithmetic sharing domain by the method in [45], so as to get the secret-shared result of the secure comparison. Based on the secure comparison method introduced above, 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇\mathsf{SecArgmin} inputs the secret-shared vector ⟦𝜹⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝜹\llbracket\boldsymbol{\delta}\rrbracket and then outputs bucket ID q∈[0,B−2]𝑞0𝐵2q\in[0,B-2] of the j𝑗j-th feature’s best test in the plaintext. In Privet, all participants can learn the produced bucket ID in the training stage, but only the participant who owns the j𝑗j-th feature can get the threshold of the j𝑗j-th feature’s best test. Since the values of the j𝑗j-th feature (denoted by 𝒟​(j)𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}(j)) is sorted in ascending order, the participant who owns the j𝑗j-th feature can get the split threshold via looking up the sorted values (i.e., πj​[𝒟​(j)]subscript𝜋𝑗delimited-[]𝒟𝑗\pi_{j}[\mathcal{D}(j)]) with index (q+1)×(N/B)𝑞1𝑁𝐵(q+1)\times(N/B). Other participants cannot deduce the split threshold because the j𝑗j-th feature is kept locally by its owner and unavailable to them.

To select the optimal test of all features, Privet lets the participants record the j𝑗j-th feature’s best bucket ID q𝑞q and secret-shared minimum split score ⟦𝜹q⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜹𝑞\llbracket\boldsymbol{\delta}_{q}\rrbracket at the j𝑗j-th position of 𝜸𝜸\boldsymbol{\gamma} and ⟦𝝈⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝝈\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket, respectively (i.e., lines 25-26 in Algorithm 6). Recall that for the J𝐽J features, we use 𝜸𝜸\boldsymbol{\gamma} and ⟦𝝈⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝝈\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket to store the bucket ID and split score of each feature’s best test. The J𝐽J indices of 𝜸𝜸\boldsymbol{\gamma} and ⟦𝝈⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝝈\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket correspond to J𝐽J features, respectively. After enumerating J𝐽J features, J𝐽J scores are stored in ⟦𝝈⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝝈\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket and 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇\mathsf{SecArgmin} is needed to be called again on ⟦𝝈⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝝈\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket. The output is the split feature Fdsubscript𝐹𝑑F_{d} of the optimal test, which is known by all participants. The optimal bucket ID qdsubscript𝑞𝑑q_{d} of the split feature can then be retrieved with Fdsubscript𝐹𝑑F_{d} from 𝜸𝜸\boldsymbol{\gamma} (line 29). After that, the participant who owns the split feature Fdsubscript𝐹𝑑F_{d} looks up the its sorted values πFd​[𝒟​(Fd)]subscript𝜋subscript𝐹𝑑delimited-[]𝒟subscript𝐹𝑑\pi_{F_{d}}[\mathcal{D}(F_{d})] with index (qd+1)×(N/B)subscript𝑞𝑑1𝑁𝐵(q_{d}+1)\times(N/B) to get the split threshold tdsubscript𝑡𝑑t_{d}.

After learning the d𝑑d-th test Fd<tdsubscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑡𝑑F_{d}<t_{d}, the participant who owns Fd<tdsubscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑡𝑑F_{d}<t_{d} cooperates with other participants to securely split all the nodes at the d𝑑d-th level with 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit} to create a new level (line 32). A decision table in Privet is learned level by level in this way. At the D𝐷D-th level, Privet securely calculates output values for the 2Dsuperscript2𝐷2^{D} leaf nodes following Eq. 3 (i.e., lines 34-37 in Algorithm 6), where the division is securely calculated with 𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏\mathsf{SDiv} in Section 5.2.2. Finally, 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖳𝖺𝖻𝗅𝖾\mathsf{SecTable} outputs a distributed decision table consisting of D𝐷D tests and 2Dsuperscript2𝐷2^{D} secret-shared output values. Specifically, all participants know the split feature Fdsubscript𝐹𝑑F_{d} at the d𝑑d-th level where d∈[0,D−1]𝑑0𝐷1d\in[0,D-1], but each split threshold tdsubscript𝑡𝑑t_{d} is only available to the participant who owns the feature Fdsubscript𝐹𝑑F_{d}.

5.3 Secure Distributed Decision Table Inference

In Privet, each decision table in the ensemble learned in the secure training phase is held by the participants in a distributed manner, where each participant holds a part of it. Recall that in our secure VFL framework (Algorithm 2), once a distributed decision table 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is securely learned in a certain round, we need to perform secure inference over the training data using 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}. The the produced inference results at this round will be securely aggreagted with previous inference results for use in securely training a new distributed decision table in the next round. To prevent the partial model and local data on each participant from leaking during the secure inference process, we propose a secure distributed decision table inference protocol 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer}, which relies on secure multiplication of indicator vectors to conduct privacy-preserving inference, as shown in Algorithm 7. 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} allows the participants to cooperatively perform secure inference on their local data utilizing the distributed ensemble and produce secret-shared inference results while keeping the local data and partial model not unavailable to other participants throughout the inference process. We introduce the design of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} as follows.

To securely produce the inference result of a vertically partitioned sample {𝐱J1,𝐱J2,⋯,𝐱Jn}superscript𝐱subscript𝐽1superscript𝐱subscript𝐽2⋯superscript𝐱subscript𝐽𝑛\{\mathbf{x}^{J_{1}},\mathbf{x}^{J_{2}},\cdots,\mathbf{x}^{J_{n}}\}, the participant Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} who owns the test Fd<tdsubscript𝐹𝑑subscript𝑡𝑑F_{d}<t_{d} at the d𝑑d-th level (d∈[0,D−1]𝑑0𝐷1d\in[0,D-1]) locally generates a leaf indicator (denoted by 𝐮dsubscript𝐮𝑑\mathbf{u}_{d}) by comparing the sample’s feature value of Fdsubscript𝐹𝑑F_{d} (represented as 𝐱Jl​(Fd)superscript𝐱subscript𝐽𝑙subscript𝐹𝑑\mathbf{x}^{J_{l}}(F_{d})) with the split threshold tdsubscript𝑡𝑑t_{d}. After that, the leaf indicator 𝐮dsubscript𝐮𝑑\mathbf{u}_{d} is secret-shared to other participants. The inference result could then be obliviously calculated by secure element-wise multiplication between the D𝐷D secret-shared leaf indicators {⟦𝐮i⟧}i=0D−1\{\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{i}\rrbracket\}_{i=0}^{D-1} and the secret-shared vector ⟦𝐰⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐰\llbracket\mathbf{w}\rrbracket of decision table’s output values. We take a 333-dimensional decision table to present the details of model distribution and 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} in Fig. 4. Without loss of generality, we assume that the tests are “H​e​i​g​h​t<170𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡170Height<170”, “W​e​i​g​h​t<60𝑊𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡60Weight<60”, and “S​a​l​a​r​y<10000𝑆𝑎𝑙𝑎𝑟𝑦10000Salary<10000”, held by participants P1,P2,P3subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3P_{1},P_{2},P_{3} , respectively, and the eight leaves’ output values are secret-shared among n𝑛n participants. In Fig. 4, it is noted that the exact test is only visible to the participant owning the corresponding feature, e.g., only P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} knows the test “H​e​i​g​h​t<170𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡170Height<170” at the 00-th level.

We take the inference of sample (“H​e​i​g​h​t=175𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡175Height=175”, “W​e​i​g​h​t=55𝑊𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡55Weight=55”, “S​a​l​a​r​y=11000𝑆𝑎𝑙𝑎𝑟𝑦11000Salary=11000”) as an example. The three features are vertically partitioned and held by P1,P2,P3subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2subscript𝑃3P_{1},P_{2},P_{3}, respectively. For the first test “H​e​i​g​h​t<170𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡170Height<170”, P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} locally compares “H​e​i​g​h​t=175𝐻𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑡175Height=175” with the threshold 170 and generate leaf indicator vector 𝐮0=(0,0,0,0,1,1,1,1)subscript𝐮000001111\mathbf{u}_{0}=(0,0,0,0,1,1,1,1) to guide the inference path because 175>170175170175>170. Similarly, we can get 𝐮1=(1,1,0,0,1,1,0,0)subscript𝐮111001100\mathbf{u}_{1}=(1,1,0,0,1,1,0,0) and 𝐮2=(0,1,0,1,0,1,0,1)subscript𝐮201010101\mathbf{u}_{2}=(0,1,0,1,0,1,0,1). Each leaf indicator vector is then secret-shared among all participants. Recall that in the basic decision table inference introduced in Section 3, the comparisons required by different Boolean tests are parallelized to accelerate inference due to the oblivious tree structure. Although the learned decision tables in the ensemble in Privet are distributed and secret-shared, their oblivious structure remains unchanged, and thus operations at different levels can still be parallelized. After the sharing of leaf indicator vectors, the inference result of this sample can be obliviously calculated by element-wise multiplication as follows: ⟦𝐮0⟧×⟦𝐮1⟧×⟦𝐮2⟧×⟦𝐰⟧\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{0}\rrbracket\times\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{1}\rrbracket\times\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{2}\rrbracket\times\llbracket\mathbf{w}\rrbracket. In this way, each participant will not know which path in the distributed decision table is used during the secure inference process.

Remark. We note that there are some existing secure distributed decision tree inference methods [7, 8] in the VFL setting. However, they are not well suited for the required secure distributed decision table inference in Privet. At a high level, these two works and Privet share the common approach of using indicator vectors to enable secure inference. However, the inherent structural differences between decision tables and decision trees result in different methods of generating and utilizing indicator vectors for guiding the inference paths during privacy-preserving inference. In secure distributed decision tree inference of [7, 8], each internal node is associated with an indicator vector, and the inference result is produced by secure multiplication of these indicator vectors. In contrast, for secure distributed decision table inference, each level in the decision table is associated with an indicator vector. As a result, existing secure distributed decision tree inference methods cannot be efficiently extended to secure distributed decision table inference. For instance, with our proposed 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} protocol and a decision table with a dimension of D=6𝐷6D=6, only six indicator vectors and six secure multiplications are needed. However, applying the method from [7, 8] to our target problem would require 26−1superscript2612^{6}-1 indicator vectors and 63 secure multiplications, resulting in poor efficiency. Moreover, the secure distributed tree inference method in [8] is not applicable in our setting because it targets a two-party setting, while Privet aims to support an arbitrary number of participants.

6 Security Analysis

Privet utilizes standard secret sharing techniques [49] to properly encrypt the intermediate information during both training and inference phases and the secret shares are uniformly distributed in a ring ℤ2Qsubscriptℤsuperscript2𝑄\mathbb{Z}_{2^{Q}}. In addition, throughout the VFL procedure, the feature data owned by each participant is kept locally. We follow the standard simulation-based paradigm [50] to analyze the security of Privet. We first define the ideal functionality of our target privacy-preserving VFL with gradient boosted decision tables as follows.

Definition 1.

The ideal functionality ℱVDTsubscriptℱVDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} of privacy-preserving VFL with gradient boosted decision tables is formulated as follows:

-Input. The input to the ℱVDTsubscriptℱVDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} consists of datasets {𝒟mN×Jm}m=1nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑁subscript𝐽𝑚𝑚𝑛𝑚1\{\mathcal{D}^{N\times J_{m}}_{m}\}^{n}_{m=1} and the label set 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} from the participants P1,P2,⋯,Pnsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2⋯subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n}.

-Computation. Upon receiving the above input, the ideal functionality ℱVDTsubscriptℱVDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} performs training of gradient boosted decision tables and produces the trained model VDT, which consists of T𝑇T decision tables.

-Output. The ideal functionality ℱVDTsubscriptℱVDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} broadcasts the split feature in the decision table to all participants, but only sends the split threshold to the participant who holds the corresponding split feature. Additionally, the ℱVDTsubscriptℱVDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} splits the output values into n𝑛n secret shares and then distributes them to the participants P1,P2,⋯,Pnsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2⋯subscript𝑃𝑛P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n}.

Definition 2.

A protocol ΠΠ\Pi securely realizes the ideal functionality ℱVDTsubscriptℱVDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} in the semi-honest adversary setting if a semi-honest participant does not learn any information about other participants’ private data and partial model. Formally, let 𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐PmΠsubscriptsuperscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐Πsubscript𝑃𝑚\mathsf{View}^{\Pi}_{P_{m}} represent participant Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m}’s view during the execution of ΠΠ\Pi. Formally, there should exist a PPT simulator, which can generate a simulated view 𝖲𝗂𝗆PmΠsubscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆Πsubscript𝑃𝑚\mathsf{Sim}^{\Pi}_{P_{m}} such that 𝖲𝗂𝗆PmΠsubscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆Πsubscript𝑃𝑚\mathsf{Sim}^{\Pi}_{P_{m}} is indistinguishable from 𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐PmΠsubscriptsuperscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐Πsubscript𝑃𝑚\mathsf{View}^{\Pi}_{P_{m}}.

Theorem 1.

Our Privet securely realizes the ideal functionality ℱVDTsubscriptℱVDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} against a semi-honest adversary who can statically corrupt a subset of τ𝜏\tau participants (τ≤n−1𝜏𝑛1\tau\leq n-1) according to Definition 2.

Proof.

If the simulator for each sub-protocol exists, then our complete protocol is secure [51, 52, 53]. As presented before, Privet consists of several secure sub-protocols: 1) secure division 𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏\mathsf{SDiv}; 2) secure Sigmoid 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽\mathsf{SecSigmoid}; 3) secure node splitting 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit}; 4) secure distributed decision table inference 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer}; 5) secure discretization 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc}; 6) secure Argmin 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇\mathsf{SecArgmin}. We use 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pm𝖷subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖷subscript𝑃𝑚\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{X}}_{P_{m}} as the simulator which can generate Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m}’s view in sub-protocol 𝖷𝖷\mathsf{X} (𝖷∈{𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏,𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽,𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍,𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋,𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼,𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇})𝖷𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇(\mathsf{X}\in\{\mathsf{SDiv},\mathsf{SecSigmoid},\mathsf{SecSplit},\mathsf{SecInfer},\mathsf{SecDisc},\mathsf{SecArgmin}\}) on corresponding input and output. Obviously, the simulators for 𝖷∈{𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏,𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽,𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇}𝖷𝖲𝖣𝗂𝗏𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗂𝗀𝗆𝗈𝗂𝖽𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇\mathsf{X}\in\{\mathsf{SDiv,SecSigmoid,SecArgmin}\} must exist, because they are comprised of basic operations in the secret sharing domain[49]. In the execution of these three protocols, even if a subset of τ𝜏\tau participants is corrupted, the honest participants’ private data will not be leaked due to the security guarantee of additive secret sharing[45]. In addition, when revealing the index of the minimum value in a secret-shared vector to all participants in 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇\mathsf{SecArgmin}, the simulator can adjust the shares of the result such that the revealed index is indeed the value received from the ideal functionality, and thus the simulator of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖠𝗋𝗀𝗆𝗂𝗇\mathsf{SecArgmin} exists. Therefore, Privet is secure if the simulators for the remaining sub-protocols exist, i.e., 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit} in Section 5.2.1, 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} in Section 5.3, 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} in Section 5.2.3. We next provide the existence of the simulators for the remaining sub-protocols. ∎

Theorem 2.

The simulators for sub-protocols 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit} and 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} exsit.

Proof.

The sub-protocols 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit} and 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer} both require that the participant who holds the split generates indicator vectors locally and then secret-shares them to other participants. For simplicity, we assume that Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} holds the split threshold and collaborates with Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l} to split the node and conduct inference. We then prove the existence of the simulators 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pl𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍subscript𝑃𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecSplit}}_{P_{l}}, 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pl𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋subscript𝑃𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecInfer}}_{P_{l}} for Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} and the simulators 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pm≠l𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍subscript𝑃𝑚𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecSplit}}_{P_{m\neq l}}, 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pm≠l𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋subscript𝑃𝑚𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecInfer}}_{P_{m\neq l}} for Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l} due to their different computation. We also note that there is no difference in the simulation between AP and PP due to their role equivalence in the execution of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit} and 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer}.

  • •

    𝖲𝗂𝗆Pl𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍subscript𝑃𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecSplit}}_{P_{l}}, 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pl𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋subscript𝑃𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecInfer}}_{P_{l}} for Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}: The simulator is simple since Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} only secret-shares its local indicator vectors and perform secure multiplications on the secret-shared vectors. In the execution of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit} and 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer}, Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} receives nothing. Moreover, since secure multiplication is the basic operation in the secret sharing domain, the privacy of the honest participants’ data is ensured even if Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} colludes with τ−1𝜏1\tau-1 participants. Therefore, it is clear that the simulated view is indistinguishable from the real view.

  • •

    𝖲𝗂𝗆Pm≠l𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍subscript𝑃𝑚𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecSplit}}_{P_{m\neq l}}, 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pm≠l𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋subscript𝑃𝑚𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecInfer}}_{P_{m\neq l}} for Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l}: In the execution of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖲𝗉𝗅𝗂𝗍\mathsf{SecSplit} and 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖨𝗇𝖿𝖾𝗋\mathsf{SecInfer}, the only information Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l} receives is the secret share (denoted by ⟨𝐫⟩m≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐫𝑚𝑙\langle\mathbf{r}\rangle_{m\neq l}) of Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}’s indicator vector 𝐫𝐫\mathbf{r}. The secret share ⟨𝐫⟩m≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐫𝑚𝑙\langle\mathbf{r}\rangle_{m\neq l} is randomly generated at Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} and thus is uniformly random in Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l}’s view. Therefore, the distribution over the real secret share ⟨𝐫⟩m≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐫𝑚𝑙\langle\mathbf{r}\rangle_{m\neq l} received by Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l} in the execution and over the simulated ⟨𝐫⟩m≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐫𝑚𝑙\langle\mathbf{r}\rangle_{m\neq l} generated by the simulator are identically distributed. Furthermore, the secure multiplication involved is the basic operation in the secret sharing domain, which means Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l} learns no additional information from the execution, even if Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l} colludes with τ−1𝜏1\tau-1 participants. Therefore, the simulated view is indistinguishable from the real view.

∎

Theorem 3.

The simulator for the sub-protocol 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} exists.

Proof.

The security of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} relies on the security of its sub-protocol 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm} because the operations in 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} besides 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm} are basic operations in the secret sharing domain. Therefore, if the protocol 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm} can be simulated, the existence of a simulator for the protocol 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc} follows. In 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆\mathsf{SecPerm}, for simplicity, we assume that Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} sorts the values for a feature locally to generate a permutation π𝜋\pi. We then prove the existence of the simulator 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pl𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscript𝑃𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecDisc}}_{P_{l}} for Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} and the simulator 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pm≠l𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscript𝑃𝑚𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecDisc}}_{P_{m\neq l}} for Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l} due to their different computation. Similarly, since the role equivalence of AP and PP in the execution of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc}, there is no difference in the analysis for them.

  • •

    𝖲𝗂𝗆Pl𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscript𝑃𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecDisc}}_{P_{l}} for Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}: In the execution of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc}, Plsubscript𝑃𝑙{P_{l}} only receives secret share ⟨𝐱−𝐫⟩m≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐱𝐫𝑚𝑙\langle\mathbf{x-r}\rangle_{m\neq l} of ⟦𝐱−𝐫⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝐱𝐫\llbracket\mathbf{x-r}\rrbracket from Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙{P_{m\neq l}} to reconstruct 𝐱−𝐫𝐱𝐫\mathbf{x-r}. In the simulated view, Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} receives n−1𝑛1n-1 random vectors. Therefore, we need to prove that ⟨𝐱−𝐫⟩m≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐱𝐫𝑚𝑙\langle\mathbf{x-r}\rangle_{m\neq l} is uniformly random in the view of Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}. Obviously, the above claim is valid, because ⟨𝐱−𝐫⟩m≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐱𝐫𝑚𝑙\langle\mathbf{x-r}\rangle_{m\neq l} is a random vector generated at Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙{P_{m\neq l}}, which must be uniformly random in the view of Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}. Therefore the distributions over the real ⟨𝐱−𝐫⟩m≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐱𝐫𝑚𝑙\langle\mathbf{x-r}\rangle_{m\neq l} received by Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} in the protocol execution and over the simulated ⟨𝐱−𝐫⟩m≠lsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝐱𝐫𝑚𝑙\langle\mathbf{x-r}\rangle_{m\neq l} are identically distributed. Moreover, even if Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} colludes with τ−1𝜏1\tau-1 participants, Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} still only learns a randomly masked version of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, thus 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} would not be leaked to Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}. Thus, the simulator for 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pl𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆subscript𝑃𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecPerm}}_{P_{l}} exists, which indicates that the simulator for 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pl𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscript𝑃𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecDisc}}_{P_{l}} also exists.

  • •

    𝖲𝗂𝗆Pm≠l𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscript𝑃𝑚𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecDisc}}_{P_{m\neq l}} for Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l}: In the execution of 𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼\mathsf{SecDisc}, Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙{P_{m\neq l}} only receives permutation πssubscript𝜋𝑠\pi_{s} from Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}. The permutation πssubscript𝜋𝑠\pi_{s} is randomly generated at Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} and is uniformly random in Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l}’s view. Therefore, the distribution over the real permutation πssubscript𝜋𝑠\pi_{s} received by Pm≠lsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑙P_{m\neq l} in the execution and over the simulated πssubscript𝜋𝑠\pi_{s} generated by the simulator is identically distributed. In case of corruption, there are two situations: 1) If participant Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} is corrupted, nothing is revealed regarding the vector 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. 2) If participant Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} is not corrupted, the private permutation π𝜋\pi on Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l} and the private vector 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} are protected, even if all other participants collude. This security guarantee comes from the fact that the corrupted participants could learn nothing about πpsubscript𝜋𝑝\pi_{p}. Without the knowledge of πpsubscript𝜋𝑝\pi_{p}, π𝜋\pi cannot be deduced because π​(⋅)=πs​[πp​(⋅)]𝜋⋅subscript𝜋𝑠delimited-[]subscript𝜋𝑝⋅\pi(\cdot)=\pi_{s}[\pi_{p}(\cdot)]. Thus, the simulator for 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pm≠l𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖯𝖾𝗋𝗆subscript𝑃𝑚𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecPerm}}_{P_{m\neq l}} exists, which indicates that the simulator for 𝖲𝗂𝗆Pm≠l𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝖾𝖼𝖣𝗂𝗌𝖼subscript𝑃𝑚𝑙\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecDisc}}_{P_{m\neq l}} also exists.

∎

7 Experiments

7.1 Setup

We implement our protocols in Python. All experiments are performed on a workstation with 16 Intel I7- 10700K cores, 64GB RAM, and 1TB SSD external storage, running Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS. It is worth mentioning that the practice of evaluating VFL algorithms on a single machine also exists in prior works [10, 7, 8, 54]. We also note that in practice, it is not common to have VFL scenarios with more than four participants since it could be hard to bring together many enterprises [9, 55]. Therefore, in our experiments, we follow prior works[7, 55, 9, 56] to conduct experiments with four participants. The communication between participants on the workstation is emulated by the loopback filesystem, where the delay is set to 5 ms and bandwidth is set to 100 Mbps.

Datasets. We use three real-world datasets to evaluate the accuracy and efficiency of Privet and three synthetic datasets to further evaluate the scalability of Privet. The synthetic datasets are generated with sklearn444https://scikit-learn.org/stable/ library. Table II summarizes the statistics of the six datasets. We divide each dataset into two parts for training and testing respectively according to the ratio of 8:2. In addition to the preprocessing in the above, each dataset is split and distributed to all participants vertically and evenly. Similar to previous works on VFL [11, 8], we assume that the records in each participant’s database have been properly aligned beforehand.

Protocol instantiation. Our protocols are instantiated using the following parameter settings. We use the ring ℤ264subscriptℤsuperscript264\mathbb{Z}_{2^{64}} with the number of precision bits l=20𝑙20l=20. The number of iterations for the reciprocal approximation is set to 20 (with 1/Y=1/2201𝑌1superscript2201/Y=1/2^{20} as the initialization). For approximating the exponential function, we set 2n=4superscript2𝑛42^{n}=4, thus the approximation requires log⁡2n=2superscript2𝑛2\log 2^{n}=2 rounds of multiplication. The hyper-parameters are public to all participants. We fix λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1 of Eq. 6 and vary the public parameter T𝑇T (the number of decision tables), B𝐵B (the number of buckets), and D𝐷D (the dimension of decision tables) in our experiments to demonstrate the utility, efficiency, and scalability of Privet.

It is noted that to handle real numbers for secure computation, we follow the common practice of fixed-point representation, where real numbers are scaled by a factor of 2lsuperscript2𝑙2^{l} (l𝑙l represents the number of precision bits) and then rounded. As a result, when two scaled values are multiplied, the result is under a scaling factor of 22​lsuperscript22𝑙2^{2l}. Therefore, truncation is required to scale down the multiplication result, making its scaling factor 2lsuperscript2𝑙2^{l} again. Privet resorts to the method in [45] to support secure truncation on a result ⟦z⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑧\llbracket z\rrbracket produced from secret-shared multiplication, which works as follows. Firstly, the secret sharing of the number of wraps (denoted by ⟦θz⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜃𝑧\llbracket\theta_{z}\rrbracket) in z𝑧z needs to be computed, which is subject to θz=(∑m=1n⟨z⟩m−z)/2Qsubscript𝜃𝑧subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑧𝑚𝑧superscript2𝑄\theta_{z}=(\sum^{n}_{m=1}\langle z\rangle_{m}-z)/2^{Q}. It is noted that to count the number of wrap rounds in this truncation protocol, computing the sum of shares (represented in the form of ∑m=1n⟨z⟩msubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑧𝑚\sum^{n}_{m=1}\langle z\rangle_{m}) does not involve modular arithmetic. The computation of ⟦θz⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜃𝑧\llbracket\theta_{z}\rrbracket proceeds as follows. All parties hold in advance a secret-shared random value ⟦r⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑟\llbracket r\rrbracket and its secret-shared wrap count ⟦θr⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜃𝑟\llbracket\theta_{r}\rrbracket subject to θr=(∑m=1n⟨r⟩m−r)/2Qsubscript𝜃𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑟𝑚𝑟superscript2𝑄\theta_{r}=(\sum^{n}_{m=1}\langle r\rangle_{m}-r)/2^{Q}. For secure truncation, all parties first compute ⟦p⟧=⟦z+r⟧\llbracket p\rrbracket=\llbracket z+r\rrbracket. After that, each party Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} computes the differential wraps produced between its shares of ⟦z⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑧\llbracket z\rrbracket, ⟦r⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑟\llbracket r\rrbracket, and ⟦p⟧delimited-⟦⟧𝑝\llbracket p\rrbracket: ⟨βz​r⟩m=(⟨z⟩m+⟨r⟩m−⟨p⟩m)/2Qsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝛽𝑧𝑟𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑧𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑟𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑝𝑚superscript2𝑄\langle\beta_{zr}\rangle_{m}=(\langle z\rangle_{m}+\langle r\rangle_{m}-\langle p\rangle_{m})/2^{Q}, where no modulo operation is required in calculating ⟨z⟩m+⟨r⟩m−⟨p⟩msubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑧𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑟𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑝𝑚\langle z\rangle_{m}+\langle r\rangle_{m}-\langle p\rangle_{m}. Next, Pm≠1subscript𝑃𝑚1P_{m\neq 1} sends ⟨p⟩m≠1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑝𝑚1\langle p\rangle_{m\neq 1} to P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} to reconstruct p𝑝p and P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} also computes θp=(∑m=1n⟨p⟩m−p)/2Qsubscript𝜃𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑛subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑝𝑚𝑝superscript2𝑄\theta_{p}=(\sum_{m=1}^{n}\langle p\rangle_{m}-p)/2^{Q}. Finally, each Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} produces the secret share ⟨θz⟩m=j×θp+⟨βz​r⟩m−⟨θr⟩msubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝜃𝑧𝑚𝑗subscript𝜃𝑝subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝛽𝑧𝑟𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝜃𝑟𝑚\langle\theta_{z}\rangle_{m}=j\times\theta_{p}+\langle\beta_{zr}\rangle_{m}-\langle\theta_{r}\rangle_{m}, where j=1𝑗1j=1 if m=1𝑚1m=1 and j=0𝑗0j=0 if m≠1𝑚1m\neq 1. Then ⟦θz⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜃𝑧\llbracket\theta_{z}\rrbracket is used to correct the truncation: ⟦z⟧=⟦z⟧−⟦θz⟧2Q2l\llbracket z\rrbracket=\frac{\llbracket z\rrbracket-\llbracket\theta_{z}\rrbracket 2^{Q}}{2^{l}}. The above method only needs 1 online communication round to compute the number of wraps ⟦θz⟧delimited-⟦⟧subscript𝜃𝑧\llbracket\theta_{z}\rrbracket, making it efficient and practical for use in Privet.

7.2 Utility Evaluation

We first compare the accuracy of two approaches: our Privet and plaintext centralized learning of gradient boosted decision tables. For the Cal Housing dataset, we set T=50𝑇50T=50 to build 505050 decision tables in the ensemble model and 555 to limit the dimension of each decision table. The number of buckets B𝐵B is set as 323232. For the Credit dataset, we set T=10𝑇10T=10, D=4𝐷4D=4 and B=32𝐵32B=32. For the Breast Cancer dataset, we set T=10𝑇10T=10, D=3𝐷3D=3 and B=32𝐵32B=32. Following other works on gradient boosting [8], more decision tables are trained for regression tasks to guarantee accuracy. We use the identical parameters in Privet and plaintext. For the regression tasks, we use the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) as the evaluation metric. For the evaluation of classification tasks, we report the results using two commonly used metrics: Accuracy (ACC) and Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC). The accuracy of Privet and plaintext on both regression and classification tasks are reported in Table III.

Fig. 5 shows the RMSE/test error on the three real-world datasets, for varying number of decision tables. Note that the test error is defined as the complement of the Accuracy (i.e., 1−limit-from11-ACC). It is observed that the difference in utility between Privet and plaintext is obvious at the very beginning, but the difference rapidly diminishes as the increase of number of decision tables in the ensemble. This indicates the similar convergence behavior of Privet and plaintext. From the above results, we can conclude that our Privet achieves compatible accuracy with plaintext centralized learning of gradient boosted decision tables on both classification and regression tasks.

7.3 Efficiency Evaluation

We now report the computation and communication performance of Privet in secure training over the three public datasets, and present the results in Table IV. We also note that to evaluate the efficiency of Privet over larger datasets, we use three synthetic datasets, of which the results are reported in Section 7.4.

From the results in the first two records of Table IV, we can observe that the training time and communication cost of Privet on Cal Housing is significantly more than that on Credit, which is because we train 50 decision tables on Cal Housing but only 10 decision tables on Credit. However, Privet consumes an average of 127 seconds to train a 5-dimensional decision table on Cal Housing and 172 seconds to train a 4-dimensional decision table on Credit. There are mainly two reasons for this observation: (1) the number of features and the number of samples of Cal Housing are less than that of Credit. (2) dealing with classification tasks additionally needs secure Sigmoid evaluation compared with regression tasks, which will result in more computation and communication overhead.

From the results in the last two records of Table IV, we can observe that although the scale of Credit is nearly 50 times larger than that of Breast Cancer, the training time on Credit under similar parameters is only roughly 4 times that on Breast Cancer. This is because Privet securely discretizes training data into buckets, and all the time-consuming computations are conducted on the buckets. In this way, the training cost is highly correlated with the number of buckets, instead of the number of training samples. In fact, this also indicates the strong scalability of Privet, which will be demonstrated in detail in the next section.

7.4 Scalability Evaluation

We now evaluate the scalability of Privet. To examine how the number of training samples and features affect the cost of secure online training, we conduct an experiment using the SynA dataset with 20,000 samples and 80 features. We report the results in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7, which show the runtime and communication cost for varying numbers of samples and features, respectively. For the experiment related to Fig. 6, we fix the number of features as 80, the dimension D𝐷D as 2, the number of buckets B𝐵B as 32, and the number of decision tables T𝑇T as 10, for varying number of training samples by randomly selecting samples from SynA. It is observed that the runtime is not much affected by the number of training samples from Fig. 6 (a). At the same time, the communication cost grows linearly with the number of training samples as shown in Fig. 6 (b). For the experiment related to Fig. 7, we randomly select 10,000 samples from SynA and fix the dimension D𝐷D as 2, the number of buckets B𝐵B as 32, and the number of decision tables T𝑇T as 10, for varying number of features by randomly selecting features from SynA. From Fig. 7 (a) and Fig. 7 (b), we can observe that both the runtime and communication cost of Privet increase proportionally with the number of features, in line with the complexity of Algorithm 6, where the main loop in each level enumerates features.

Next, we examine the impact of dimension D𝐷D, the number of buckets B𝐵B, and the number of decision tables T𝑇T on the runtime of secure training. We use the synthetic regression dataset SynB with 20,000 samples and 60 features for the regression task, and the synthetic classification dataset SynC with 20,000 samples and 40 features for the classification task. We first examine the relationship between dimension D𝐷D and runtime. For both regression and classification tasks, we set B𝐵B = 32, T𝑇T = 10, and vary the dimension D𝐷D, over varying number of training samples. The results are shown in Fig. 8 (a) and Fig. 9 (a), from which we can observe that the runtime grows exponentially with the increase of dimension. The results are consistent with the complexity of our secure training algorithm because the number of tree nodes is exponentially related to the dimension. The computation in each node accounts for the largest proportion of all calculations. We then examine the relationship between the number of buckets B𝐵B and runtime. We set T𝑇T = 10, D𝐷D = 2, and vary B𝐵B, over varying number of training samples. The evaluation is also performed over both SynB and SynC. Fig. 8 (b) and Fig. 9 (b) show the results, which indicate the linear association between B𝐵B and runtime. Finally, we evaluate the relationship between the number of decision tables T𝑇T and runtime, and summarize the results in Fig. 8 (c) and Fig. 9 (c). We set T𝑇T from 5 to 25, while keeping B𝐵B = 32 and D𝐷D = 2, on both SynB and SynC with varying number of training samples. Recall that in Privet an ensemble of decision tables is securely built. The training time of each decision table is roughly the same when we set the same parameters for them. So the runtime must grow linearly with the number of decision tables, which is consistent with the results in Fig. 8 (c) and Fig. 9 (c). In summary, the above evaluation results demonstrate that Privet is scalable and capable of handling large-scale datasets with a large number of features and training samples.

8 Conclusion

In this paper, we design, implement, and evaluate Privet, the first system framework enabling privacy-preserving VFL service for gradient boosted decision tables. Building on lightweight secret sharing techniques, Privet supports an arbitrary number of distributed participants to collaboratively train gradient boosted decision tables over vertically partitioned distributed datasets, offering strong protection for individual data as well as for intermediate outputs. Extensive experiments on several real-world datasets and synthetic datasets demonstrate that Privet achieves promising performance, with model utility comparable to the case of plaintext centralized learning. For future work, it would be an interesting direction to explore the possibility of leveraging GPUs to achieve further performance boost.
